I have been starting to learn R and Python for data science and following the typical route of videos and practice projects. I really want to ramp up my learning and exposure to different ways. Here is my proposal:

- Gather a small group of 2-5 and learn together.
- Meet at a coffee shop, library, or some other space that has Wi-Fi.
- Pick a project, data set or problem, then work to solve it with different tools.
- Keep it fluid and informal.
- Meet on a regular basis, say weekly to start, and adjust as needed.
- Aim to keep the meetings 2-4 hours long, but this can be adjusted to the project or group. People can come and go as needed.
- It does not have to be the same people each time, so you only have to commit to going once to check it out.

Are you interested? Show up at the meeting spot, have some coffee, meet new friends and bring a project or question.

title: Berlin R Users Group: #45 A long-short Bayesian State-Space model with R and RStan  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
18:30 Intro
18:35 Talk
19:05 Q&A
19:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language): shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps (June useR Meetup)  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Greater Boston useR Group (R Programming Language)
description:
shiny.fluent and shiny.react: Build beautiful Shiny apps using Microsoft's Fluent UI
Presentation by Kamil Å»yÅ‚a

Abstract:
In this talk we will present the functionality and ideas behind a new open-source package Appsilon developed called shiny.fluent. UI plays a huge role in the success of Shiny projects. shiny.fluent enables you to build Shiny apps in a novel way using Microsoftâ€™s Fluent UI as the UI foundation. It gives your app a beautiful, professional look and a rich set of components while retaining the speed of development that Shiny is famous for.

Fluent UI is based on the Javascript library React, so itâ€™s a challenging task to make it work with Shiny. We have put the parts responsible for making this possible in a separate package called shiny.react, which enables you to port other React-based components and UI libraries so that they work in Shiny.

During the talk we will demonstrate how to use shiny.fluent to build your own Shiny apps, and explain how we solved the main challenges in integrating React and Shiny

Speaker Bio:
Kamil is a Full Stack Engineer at Appsilon. He graduated with degrees in Computer Science and Mathematics from the University of Warsaw. He is passionate about working across various technologies, leading projects, and developing internal tooling. Privately, he enjoys listening to
jazz and has an interest in psychology and philosophy.

title: Montreal R User Group: Speed Optimization & Benchmarks in Spark NLP 3: Making the Most of Hardware  [Virtual] , Canada, US/Canada
description:
Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

Spark NLP is the most widely used NLP library in the enterprise, thanks to implementing production-grade, trainable, and scalable versions of state-of-the-art deep learning & transfer learning NLP research. It is also Open Source with a permissive Apache 2.0 license that officially supports Python, Java, and Scala languages backed by a highly active community and JSL members.

Spark NLP library implements core NLP algorithms including lemmatization, part of speech tagging, dependency parsing, named entity recognition, spell checking, multi-class and multi-label text classification, sentiment analysis, emotion detection, unsupervised keyword extraction, and state-of-the-art Transformers such as BERT, ELECTRA, ELMO, ALBERT, XLNet, and Universal Sentence Encoder.

The latest release of Spark NLP 3.0 comes with over 1100+ pretrained models, pipelines, and Transformers in 190+ different languages. It also delivers massive speeds up on both CPU & GPU devices while extending support for the latest computing platforms such as new Databricks runtimes and EMR versions.

The talk will focus on how to scale Apache Spark / PySpark applications in YARN clusters, use GPU in Databricks new Apache Spark 3.x runtimes, and manage large-scale datasets in resource-demanding NLP applications efficiently. We will share benchmarks, tips & tricks, and lessons learned when scaling Spark NLP.

Register: https://events.johnsnowlabs.com/speed-optimization-benchmarks-in-spark-nlp-3-making-the-most-of-modern-hardware

Itâ€™s happened again. You built another AI model that will never see the light of day because it wonâ€™t make it past the AI â€œvalley of deathâ€ â€“ the crossover of model development to model deployment across your enterprise. The handoff between data science and engineering teams is fraught with friction, outstanding questions around governance and accountability, and who is responsible for different parts of the pipeline and process. Even worse? The patchwork approach when building an AI pipeline leaves many organizations open to risks because of a lack of a holistic approach to security and monitoring.

Join us to learn about approaches and solutions for configuring a ModelOps pipeline thatâ€™s right for your organization. Youâ€™ll discover why itâ€™s never too early to plan for operationalization of models, regardless of whether your organization has 1, 10, 100, or 1,000 models in production.

The discussion will also reveal the merits of an open container specification that allows you to easily package and deploy models in production from everywhere. Finally, new approaches for monitoring model drift and explainability will be revealed that will help manage expectations with business leaders all through a centralized AI software platform called ModzyÂ®.

title: Cleveland R User Group: Jai Ranchod on pdftools and Bryan Lewis on DuckDB  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
This meetup we'll have two shorter talks by Jai Ranchod and Bryan Lewis. Details below.

Talk 1: Jai Ranchod - Extract tabular data from PDFs with pdftools

I'm going to be talking about how to pull tabular data out of a PDF based on partial string matching and some functions in the "PDF Tools" package. The need to do this presented itself when the president of the management company wanted a table of information for the 60+ properties in our portfolio and our software vendor said they could only give us PDFs of word docs.

Jai ("Jay") Ranchod is currently an Operations and Financial Analyst are Rose Community Management, a property management firm based in NYC with offices in Independence, OH. I started using R at my previous job at Epic Systems which is an electronic healthcare record company as part of the quality control process on their cognitive computing products. Since then I have taken several online classes in R, data science, and machine learning including a professional certificate program in data science taught using R. I have a bachelor's degree in physics from the College of Wooster and recently finished my MBA from John Carroll University.

Talk 2: Bryan Lewis - R and DuckDB

DuckDB (https://duckdb.org) is a new embedded SQL database library in the spirit of other embedded databases like SQLite. Unlike SQLite, DuckDB uses a column-oriented data layout (like R data frames) and has a particular focus on performance for interactive data analysis. DuckDB's integration with R is so complete that it can work directly on in-memory language objects without copying. This lets you use DuckDB directly on R data frames, including excellent support for dplyr.

I'll show some practical examples of R and DuckDB and share my thoughts how to best use these technologies together.

Bryan Lewis is a mathematician, author of the irlba and threejs R packages, and coauthor of the recent CRC textbook "A Computational Approach to Statistical Learning." He previously worked on Mike Stonebraker's open-source SciDB array database project.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Cleveland R User Group: Trang Le: Take a sad chart and make it better  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Every good chart started out as a bad one. In this talk, we will discuss a few basic visualization principles and some ggplot tips and tricks that help improve our charts and refine our data stories. Some familiarity with R and ggplot will be useful but not required - novice R users are encouraged to attend.

Trang Le is a postdoctoral fellow with Jason Moore at the Computational Genetics Lab, University of Pennsylvania. She enjoys developing machine learning methods for rigorous analyses of a wide array of biomedical data. Most recently, her work focuses on investigating the long-term effect of neurological conditions in COVID-19 patients. Sheâ€™s the author and maintainer of multiple R packages.

Note: this talk will be recorded and posted on our YouTube channel.

title: Salt Lake City R Users Group: Create infographics with R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: Salt Lake City R Users Group
description:
Our August Meetup will be a remote gathering; the Zoom link will be posted the week of the event.

Infographics are everywhere, and when well-designed can be a fantastic way of sharing data highlights in an engaging and visually appealing way to non-technical audiences. Typically infographics are custom made by a graphic designer who has been provided the numbers that will be represented in the graphic, and therefore can be time-intensive to produce. Producing more than one infographic of the same design to display different values (for instance, for different geographical areas) has a linear increase in production time for each n+1 graphic once the basic design time has been accounted for. This talk will describe a novel method for producing infographics using R that allows for dynamically adjusting the graphical elements based on any number of data values and rapidly producing bespoke versions. A walkthrough of the process used to create 3,142 custom infographics (one for each county in the US) will be presented to illustrate the process.

Jonathan Zadra, PhD is a Director of Data Science at the non-profit Sorenson Impact Center in Salt Lake City, Utah. He combines his skills in statistics, programming, and data visualization with expertise in data privacy and policy to empower governments, nonprofits, and philanthropists working in a wide array of issue areas. His areas of focus include criminal justice data (including work with the PEW Charitable Trusts, Utah Department of Corrections, Utah Indigent Defense Commission, and Utah Commission on Criminal and Juvenile Justice), early- and higher-education data including a multi-year project supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, as well as other issue areas like homelessness or poverty, and has worked on many smaller projects building evaluations and impact measurements for a variety of social-good non-profits around the country. He received his doctorate from the University of Virginia, where he studied cognitive science and neuroscience and designed and conducted rigorous RCTs - and also fell in love with R way back in 2006!

title: Wiesbaden R User Group: R Coffee Break XL:  modeling linguistic variation in R  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Hallo liebe R User,

Die R Coffee Break gibt einen kurzen Einblick in ein R- Thema. Als Plattform nutzen wir Zoom.
Und ganz wie die gepflegte Kaffeepause im BÃ¼ro wird das Meetup am Nachmittag stattfinden. Achtung: Dieses Mal haben wir eine XL-Kaffeepause von 30 Minuten.

Wir freuen uns, dass Claus Weihs und Sarah Buschfeld von derTU Dortmund University Ã¼ber ihre Arbeit im Bereich der Lingusistik vortragen. Hier ist ihre VortragsankÃ¼ndigung:

Combining Prediction and Interpretation in Decision Trees (PrInDT): modeling linguistic variation in R
In this presentation, we show that conditional inference trees and ensembles are suitable methods for modeling linguistic variation. As against earlier linguistic applications, however, we claim that their suitability is strongly increased if we combine prediction and interpretation. To that end, we have developed a statistical method in R, PrInDT (Prediction and Interpretation with Decision Trees), which we introduce and discuss in our presentation.

* Es handelt sich um einen englischsprachigen Vortrag.
* Es ist ein 30-minÃ¼tiger Vortrag

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by Brighton R: June Meetup  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

At the next Brighton R meetup, we will be joined by two fantastic speakers, and weâ€™re excited to reveal that our first speaker is Tobias Stalder

'ggameboy'. Or what else we can do with ggplot2

We are pleased to welcome Tobias Stalder, Project Associate R&D at Grolimund+Partner AG, to talk at the next Brighton R meetup.

Tobias will be sharing how he built a cool data visualisation package using ggplot2 that allows you to create custom coloured Gameboy pictures!

The gameboy_plot() function allows you to change the colours of every aspect of a Gameboy wireframe, including the ability to add custom screen text messages.

So, if youâ€™re interested in learning about some fun data visualisation things you can get up to with your data in ggplot2, then this is a talk not to be missed!

Following the presentation, you will have an opportunity to ask questions about the project and chat with others from the local Brighton R community.

ggplot2 is part of the tidyverse ecosystem of R packages, which allows you to assign variables to your data and then map onto aesthetics. You can checkout Tobiasâ€™s Github here, which includes a repository about the ggameboy project.

More speakers to be announced soon!

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event by R Lille: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets}  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/R-Lille/events/277902715/

[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: Barcelona R User Group: Online event BerlinRUG: A long-short Bayesian State-Space model w/ R and RStan  [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
Hello everyone! We would like to invite you to join a fellow R group event organised online. Please see event details below:
----------------------------------------------

Original Meetup: https://www.meetup.com/Berlin-R-Users-Group/events/278030316/

Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
18:30 Intro
18:35 Talk
19:05 Q&A
19:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

title: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup: Text Preprocessing in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
group: New York Open Statistical Programming Meetup
description:
Continuing virtually, this month we have a talk about text preprocessing.

Thank you to EcoHealth Alliance for providing the Zoom link.

Conversations during the meetup are encouraged in the monthly-meetup-chat channel in the nyhackr slack: https://nyhackr.org/slack.html

Outside the meetups we have two events planned:

The 2021 R Conference in NY, September 8-10 as both in-person and virtual: https://rstats.ai/nyr/
The Bayes and Stan workshop, July 14-16, fully virtual: https://www.tickettailor.com/events/landeranalytics/505284

About the Talk:
Text constitutes an ever-growing part of the data available to us today. However, it is a non-trivial task to transform text, represented as long strings of characters, into numbers that we can use in our statistical and machine learning models. This talk will focus on the {textrecipes} package and its recent advancements in the realm of text preprocessing.

About Emil:
Emil Hvitfeldt is a clinical data analyst working in healthcare, and an adjunct professor at American University teaching statistical machine learning with tidymodels. He is also an open-source R developer and author of the {textrecipes} package.

The talk will begin at 7 PM EDT and we will start admitting people to the event shortly before. Since this is completely remote there will be no pizza but everyone is encouraged to have pizza individually.

The tutorial is designed for R users from a variety of fields who are interested in working with spatial data and creating maps with R.

No knowledge of cartography is required.

Prior knowledge of (non-spatial) graphic making and data handling with the {tidyverse} in R is recommended.

Speaker Bio:

Dorris Scott is the GIS Librarian and Social Science Data Curator at Washington University â€“ St. Louis, where she provides consultation on projects that use geospatial data along with providing training in various GIS software, programming applications of geospatial data, and data management. She also serves as a liaison between Washington University Libraries and social science departments assisting faculty with their data needs such as data management and data curation. Dorris received her PhD in Geography from the University of Georgia, with a specialization in GIS applications for public health.

[Zoom Link will be emailed 3 days before the event.]

title: R-Ladies Boulder: RLadies Boulder Meetup #15: From csv to slippy map - intro to spatial data in R  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
Hi Boulder UseRs! Join us for this month's virtual R Ladies Meetup! This month, Anna Spiers will be giving us an introduction to spatial data and map-making in R!

From Anna: Working with spatial data can feel as finicky as caring for your favorite houseplant - your attempts to help are rejected despite following instructions, and you look longingly at friends' and colleagues' masterpieces (i.e., maps/plants). This talk will introduce spatial data broadly, and cover some of the basic workflows and troubleshooting steps in R. Specifically, we will work with vector data, focus on the `sp` and `sf` libraries, and produce an interactive map in R. Example data and code will be provided.

We will be meeting over Zoom (Meeting link visible when you RSVP). Join us to connect with other R users in the Boulder area and learn some new techniques to apply in your work!

We hope you'll also join our local Slack workspace to keep the R help and conversation flowing! To get access to the Slack workspace, please fill out this short Google form: https://forms.gle/j36YGxuNwN6zZ8nW7.

Speakers and talk titles:

* Shannon Pileggi - Leveraging the R community for the job interview

Shannon Pileggi (@PipingHotData) is an enthusiastic statistical collaborator and educator with experience partnering on data analysis in corporate, tech, and government settings. Shannon is currently a Senior Statistician at Adelphi Research in Doylestown, PA working in pharmaceutical market research. Shannonâ€™s day-to-day in R include: fine-tuning ggplots to convey analysis results, contributing to an internal package to automate routine analyses/tasks, streamlining work-flows for repetitive analyses, and developing shiny aps.

* Alice Walsh - Data nightmares: True stories for scary data

Alice Walsh (@sciencealice), Ph.D. is a computational biologist who studies diseases at the molecular level. She is also an organizer of R-Ladies Philly and enjoys data cleaning, generating hypotheses from complex data, and mentoring others.

* Zhenya Cherkas - Rshiny : connecting the silos

Zhenya Cherkas is an Associate Director at Johnson & Johnson Global Medical Safety. Using R for over 15 years, she always worked on the better access and use of multiple disconnected data sources for better data science in less time. She holds PhD in Statistics, MS and BS in Mathematics and BS in Applied Mathematics and Computer Science.

* Jake Riley - Headliner: a new package for dynamic insights

Jake Riley is a data analyst at CHOP and the author of several R packages to improve the workflow of data analysis. His new R package, [headliner], allows users to generate dynamic, informative titles for charts and reports. Read more here https://rjake.github.io/headliner/"

* June Choe - Using icon fonts for data viz

June Choe (@yjunechoe) is a PhD student in Linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, where he studies the mechanisms of human language acquisition and processing. He enjoys blogging about R and reading about data visualization in his free time.

Her research broadly looks at digital media and risky decision making using a behavioral and neuroimaging approach. In her free time, she enjoys exploring the Philly food scene and practicing yoga!

title: R-Ladies Sydney: Building a Personal Website Using R , Australia, Australia
description:

This workshop will be an interactive presentation, where we will build a website together (like Jenny's site here https://jennysloane.netlify.app/ from scratch. We will also provide further resources that will allow you to continue enhancing your website on your own.

To prepare for this workshop please make sure that you have R and RStudio installed on your computer. It would be great if you could create a Github account if you do not have one already.

Please bring your laptop with you!

NOTE: We are back to running workshops IN PERSON- YAY! Thank you to Nous for their generous support. The COVID-safe room limit is 20 attendees so please only RSVP if you are sure you can come.

BIOS

Tehilla is a Ph.D. student studying cognitive science at UNSW, Sydney. She received her Bachelor and Masters of Science degrees from the University of Basel, Switzerland. Her research focuses on the interaction between risky decision-making and information-seeking behaviour.

Jenny is also a PhD student studying cognitive psychology at UNSW. She received her BA in psychology from the University of Maryland and her Masters of Science in experimental psychology from Syracuse University. Jennyâ€™s research interests include studying the effects of interruptions and time-pressure on decision-making.

title: R-Ladies Brisbane: Introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R  [Virtual] , Australia, Australia
description:
*What are we going to learn:
Docker is a platform for creating â€œcontainersâ€ on your system. You can think of them like a mini system on your computer. They are completely self-contained, isolated environments on your system. These containers include their own operating system, application software, scripts, data, etc. Containers are useful for a lot of things, but here Iâ€™ll focus on a quick introduction to using Docker for reproducibility in R. I will demonstrate on how to set-up Docker, run R on a Docker container and few other use cases.

*Who is going to present:
Malindrie is a PhD candidate at the Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology, The University of Queensland. She works on developing bioinformatics methods for the analysis of large-scale single-cell data using advanced statistical modelling and uses modern statistics tools to understand human disease. Malindrie completed her Bachelor of Science (Honours) degree in Statistics in 2016.

* When are we meeting?
The talk will start at 5:00 pm for approximately 45 mins and 15 min Q&A. After that we invite you to stay for in-person and/or virtual catch up.

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: From messy data to beautiful plot: Guided TidyTuesday  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Know the basics of data wrangling but want some hands-on practice? Want to learn ggplot tips and tricks to make your plots eye-catching? Seen cool visualizations on Twitter but find it hard to go from messy dataset to beautiful visualization?

In this monthly meetup, weâ€™ll go through a Tidy Tuesday dataset together step-by-step, walking you through the entire process from coming up with an interesting question to asnwer, getting the data in the right format and finally, creating a cool visualization!

You may have heard of Tidy Tuesday -- a weekly initiative by R for Data Science which provides a new dataset every week for the community to practice wrangling and visualizing. It has a huge Twitter community and is one of the best ways to practice and develop tidyverse skills, whether youâ€™re still reviewing the basics or have quite the repertoire. This series has something for everyone and is especially designed to be beginner friendly!

It's important to us to ensure that Guided Tidy Tuesday is a safe space for gender minorities and especially those who are just starting out with R. Studies have shown that letting gender minorities speak first promotes a welcoming and supportive atmosphere for underrepresented groups. All are welcome at this meetup but we specifically ask cisgender men to take a passive role in this meetup and hold comments / questions until after others have had the chance to ask. Thank you for your support!

title: R-Ladies Freiburg: Tidy Text Analysis: Word frequencies & n-grams  [Virtual] , Germany, Europe
description:
Text is one of the most prominent and extensive data sources in the digital world. It can be an insight into consumer opinions, social media trends, and literary story arches. However, it can be difficult to analyze without specialized tools and commands. The tidytext package and framework makes it easy to go from full text files to clean data and ultimately, analysis!

The workshop will start with the building blocks of text analysis: separating a text into smaller chunks, removing punctuation, and identifying frequent words or phrases. If youâ€™ve joined our previous text analysis meetups before, this will be a great recap; if you havenâ€™t, this will bring you right up to speed! Weâ€™ll show you all you need to know so beginners to the topic are very much welcome.

The focus for the evening will be on going beyond individual words in isolation to n-grams: units of a set number of words (e.g. bigrams like â€œI thinkâ€, â€œthink thatâ€, â€œthat tidytextâ€, â€œtidytext isâ€, â€œis greatâ€.). This will allow us to get a sense of context about words based on the company they keep and address typical text analysis problems (e.g. "happy" preceded by "not" being given a positive sentiment score).

Weâ€™ll top it all off with some truly unique visualizations that show the relationship between words, like bigram network plots with ggraph. Materials will be based on the book Tidy Text Mining by Julia Silge and David Robinson (chapter 4).

title: AthensR: Reproducible Computation at Scale in R with {targets} [R Lille]  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
[Abstract]
The {targets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/) R package enhances the reproducibility, scale, and maintainability of data science projects in computationally intense fields such as machine learning, Bayesian data analysis, and statistical genomics. {targets} resolves the dependency structure of the analysis pipeline, skips tasks that are already up to date, executes the rest with optional distributed computing, and manages data storage. {stantargets} (https://docs.ropensci.org/stantargets/) and similar packages extend {targets} to simplify pipeline construction for specialized use cases such as the validation of Bayesian models.

[Bio]
Will Landau (https://wlandau.github.io/) works at Eli Lilly and Company (https://www.lilly.com/) where he develops methods and tools for clinical statisticians, and he is the creator and maintainer of the targets and drake R packages. Will earned his PhD in Statistics at Iowa State University in 2016, where his dissertation research applied Bayesian methods, hierarchical models, and GPU computing to the analysis of RNA-seq data.

[About]
This event (in English) is organised by the R Lille user group (Lille, France).

title: AthensR: A long-short Bayesian State-Space model with R and RStan (Berlin RUG #45)  [Virtual] , Greece, Europe
description:
Welcome to our 2nd own Berlin RUG online meetup! We'll learn about bayesian modeling for a forecast on our upcoming election. And we will get to see each other again, so we're hoping many will sign up :)

A long-short Bayesian State-Space model for the German Federal Election 2021 with R and RStan

# Description
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert will present a Bayesian model for forecasting the German federal election 2021 with R and RStan that gives more insights and more accurate predictions compared to simple poll-averaging methods. The model consists of two parts:
A model for the election outcome (i.e. the vote share for each party based on poll data) and a model to assign a probability to the coalition of the actual government using expert survey data. An in-depth description and motivation is discussed in this talk. The model is fitted with (R)Stan, a Bayesian modeling framework, that can seamlessly be integrated into R.

# Agenda
19:30 Intro
19:35 Talk
20:05 Q&A
20:30 Closing remarks (we can extend it if needed)

# Bios
Marcus GroÃŸ and Michelle Golchert are Data Scientists at INWT Statistics.
Marcus holds a Ph.D. in Statistics and has several years experience consulting on and managing projects in the data science field. He is an expert in predictive analytics and Bayesian statistics.
Michelle has a master's degree in psychology and specializes in supporting Data Science projects in the areas of software development, DevOps and CI.

Speaker Bio:

Dorris Scott is the GIS Librarian and Social Science Data Curator at Washington University â€“ St. Louis, where she provides consultation on projects that use geospatial data along with providing training in various GIS software, programming applications of geospatial data, and data management. She also serves as a liaison between Washington University Libraries and social science departments assisting faculty with their data needs such as data management and data curation. Dorris received her PhD in Geography from the University of Georgia, with a specialization in GIS applications for public health.

title: R-Ladies Madrid: Empezando con clusterizaciÃ³n   [Virtual] , Spain, Europe
description:
En esta sesiÃ³n comenzaremos a explorar cÃ³mo de potentes son los mÃ©todos de clusterizaciÃ³n para solucionar mÃºltiples problemas y lo haremos a travÃ©s de varios ejemplos.

Lo aprenderemos de la mano de Elena Rivas Ruzafa (https://www.linkedin.com/in/elena-rivas-ruzafa/) , Head of Engineering - Digital Products que durante la sesiÃ³n nos guiarÃ¡ y aprenderemos mediante ejemplos.

Dentro del machine learning, la clusterizaciÃ³n se enmarca dentro del aprendizaje no supervisado, es decir, esos algoritmos para los que solo disponemos de un conjunto de datos de entrada que no estÃ¡n etiquetados y sobre los que obtendremos informaciÃ³n sin conocer de antemano cuÃ¡l serÃ¡ la respuesta correcta. Esta situaciÃ³n se da muy a menudo y provocarÃ¡ que la forma en la que hemos de testear los resultados sea muy particular. TambiÃ©n veremos que la creaciÃ³n de visualizaciones de datos y la generaciÃ³n de grÃ¡ficos, se convertirÃ¡ en una parte esencial de la exploraciÃ³n de dichos resultados.

Lo que obtendremos tras el proceso de clusterizaciÃ³on serÃ¡ una segmentaciÃ³n de los datos en grupos similares que serÃ¡n lo que conocemos como â€œclÃºsteresâ€. Aunque es un problema de clasificaciÃ³n no debemos confundir clusterizaciÃ³n con clasificaciÃ³n. Ambos son mÃ©todos de identificaciÃ³n de patrones, pero mientras el primero pertenece al aprendizaje no supervisado, el segundo, mÃ¡s conocido, pertenece al aprendizaje supervisado. TambiÃ©n trataremos de explicar estas diferencias.

AdemÃ¡s de resolver algunos casos prÃ¡cticos durante la sesiÃ³n, veremos cÃ³mo estos mÃ©todos pueden solucionar diferentes problemas en mÃºltiples Ã¡mbitos (en medicina para el diagnÃ³stico de enfermedades, en redes sociales para encontrar grupos de comportamiento similares, en finanzas para generar estrategias dirigidas a los diferentes grupos de clientes...)

Todo esto lo haremos en el entorno de programaciÃ³n R en el que existen mÃºltiples paquetes que implementan algoritmos de clustering y funciones para visualizar sus resultados. Durante la sesiÃ³n trabajaremos con algunos de los mÃ¡s interesantes.

title: R-Ladies Amsterdam: [ONLINE]- R in Production  [Virtual] , Netherlands, Europe
description:
Hi, everybody!
We are super excited to have Veerle van Leemput with us, Managing Director and Head of Data Science from Analytic Health- sharing her knowledge with us on how to run R in production!

DESCRIPTION
-------------------
We often hear that R canâ€™t be used for production, but is this true? Isnâ€™t the statement that R is â€˜just a research-only language mainly used by academiaâ€™ outdated?

Spoiler alert: you definitely can use R in production. From ETL to (Shiny) web applications to machine learning models: some of the main business processes at Analytic Health are powered by R. During this talk, Veerle will dive into what â€œproductionâ€ means and how you can use R in a context outside of academia. By showing how R is being used at Analytic Health and how processes and applications are deployed and managed we hope to show you that R can do more than statistics only. This talk will inspire you to take R one step further, and by providing pointers to which tools you can use to build robust processes youâ€™ll leave this talk ready to use R in production yourself!

ABOUT VEERLE
---------------------

Veerle is an entrepreneur and Data Scientist who gets excited about data and programming. She is Managing Director and Head of Data Science at Analytic Health, a UK-based company that develops intelligent and accessible technology which gives organisations the tools they need to accelerate innovation in healthcare. She is a R developer with a Masterâ€™s Degree in Data Science and multiple years of experience in the pharmaceutical market. Besides programming in R (and Shiny) she also develops multiple web applications for healthcare organisations using Vue.js and Node.

description:
Registration is required on the AlphaZetta site - links below.

The AlphaZetta Global Analytics Summit is a unique conference experience, built around experts sharing their knowledge, use cases, best practice and having time for meaningful interactions. It is not vendor driven - thereâ€™s no booths or selling and no big crowds - we expect only ~150 attendees. The summit provides insightful presentations, fantastic networking and discussion time at great value!

We are aiming to host GAS in Sydney on Friday 20th August at the Manly Pacific Hotel. Further details including the agenda can be found here ( https://alphazetta.ai/event/global-analytics-summit-sydney-2020/ ).

title: R-Ladies Tbilisi: First steps on Git using R-Studio and GitHub  [Virtual] , Georgia, Asia
description:
This R-Ladies Tbilisi meetup is happy to welcome Elisa Schneider (see bio below)! During this workshop we will introduce the concept of version control using Git, RStudio and GitHub. We will learn the basic Git commands and how to use them directly from R-Studio. Elisa Schneider will show how to link your R-Projects with GitHub to create online repositories to share your work and how it can be used for collaboration. At the end she will do a short demo on uploading a small WebPage to Github such as the one from R-Ladies Seattle https://github.com/rladies-seattle/rladies-seattle-organizing. If we have enough time she will introduce other possibilities such as GitHub Webpages like this one: https://kyla-mcconnell.github.io/website/index.html.

If you have some time to prepare before the Meetup, Elisa recommends to:
Â· create a GitHub account (if you do not have one yet) on https://github.com/
Â· download and install Git from https://git-scm.com/

For the last part of the meetup some very basic knowledge of markdown/Rmarkdown is recommended, but not mandatory, we will also go through it. If you want, you can have a look at the first 35 minutes of this video about RMarkdown: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H91WSwALx1A

Bio
Elisa Schneider comes from Argentina. She studied Biology and also got a degree on Science Education. She specialized in Remote Sensing data analysis and Geographic Information Systems (GIS). She practiced as environmental assessment consultant and also taught cartography and GIS for park rangers. Thanks to a scholarship from the German Academic Exchange Service she was able to complete a master on Environmental Modeling in 2019, at the University of Freiburg. Since then she has been working on the Forest Reaserch Institute of Baden-WÃ¼rttemberg, Germany evaluating forest health from remote sensing data, modeling species distribution and outbreaks of pest insects under climate change. In 2019 she joined R-Ladies Freiburg as a Co-Organizer.

description:
In questo evento siamo lieti di ospitare un workshop pratico di Bene Assicurazioni, che condividerÃ  con noi come stanno risolvendo le loro sfide quotidiane utilizzando R & big data.

Bene Assicurazioni Ã¨ una realtÃ  in crescita dalla struttura agile, con molteplici partnership e un modello di business in omni-canalitÃ . La Compagnia ha completato la digitalizzazione dei processi e crede nel continuo aggiornamento delle tecnologie adottate.

Il team BI&A Ã¨ un gruppo in crescita e con una posizione centrale nella compagnia; Ã¨ un gruppo giovane, dinamico che si occupa:

Della diffusione della â€œcultura dei numeriâ€ allâ€™interno della Compagnia
Del governo integrato della reportistica, degli indicatori di performance e di marginalitÃ  tecnica
Delle analisi predittive, tecniche e attuariali per ottimizzare il pricing competitivo, la retention e lo sviluppo di nuovi prodotti
Dato il piano di crescita della compagnia, molto ambizioso nel breve-medio termine e da effettuarsi senza intaccare la marginalitÃ , abbiamo studiato con diversi modelli predittivi come modificare il prodotto e il pricing per ottimizzare le nostra crescita, ottenendo infine risultati in linea con le aspettative (Machine Learning works!).

In questo workshop presentiamo il problema ed entriamo nei dettagli di alcuni dei modelli, dei test effettuati e del codice utilizzato per raggiungere il nostro obiettivo.

L'evento sarÃ  in Italiano e sarÃ  trasmesso in streaming tramite Zoom (Non Ã¨ necessario installare zoom).

title: R-Ladies New York: Data Visualization: Color Palettes, Themes, and Schemes  [Virtual] , United States, US/Canada
description:
For our June event, R-Ladies Anna Sofia Kircher and Joyce Robbins will share short talks about using color palettes, themes, and schemes to improve data visualization in R.

This event will be hosted over Zoom, and the link will be available on this Meetup page at noon on the day of the event.

Agenda (times approximate):
7-7:05 pm: R-Ladies NYC Announcements
7:05-7:30: â€œggplot and Iâ€ by Anna Sofia Kircher
7:30-7:55: â€œDoes your color palette match your data?â€ by Joyce Robbins
7:55-8:15: Questions and wrap-up

--- Talk Abstract ---

â€œggplot and Iâ€
Speaker: Anna Sofia Kircher

Abstract: This talk will be about how to use ggplot themes and how to personalize them for your purposes. This is motivated by my own obsession with colors and my own experience that different plots with different audiences respond differently to different themes.

Bio: Anna Sofia Kircher is the data scientist at Lendable and works with data of various fintechs in emerging and frontier markets.

â€œDoes your color palette match your data?â€
Speaker: Joyce Robbins

Abstract: One of the most common graphical mistakes is choosing an inappropriate color scheme for your data. In this talk, Iâ€™ll explain how sequential, diverging and qualitative color schemes are each suited to a different type of data. Weâ€™ll then look at a variety of plots that could be improved with alternative color choices. My hope is that these examples will serve as conversation starters for a lively discussion on matching color to data.

Bio: Joyce Robbins (@jtrnyc) is a Lecturer in the Department of Statistics at Columbia University. She specializes in data visualization and statistical literacy.

---
